comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Plus, can't believe that I missed our 2nd Anniversary on Flickr Commons! We launched on 1 June 2011. Would just like to wish us all a very happy anniversary (what's a second anniversary - is it paper?). Thank you all for making this "marriage" lively, interesting and fun. And we almost never shout at each other about map reading!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91870729@N06
comment._content: I think I can see 6 Ladies with wrist watches and 1 Gentleman with a wrist watch and 1 with a pocket watch on a fob.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Those ladies using croquet hammers would obviously struggle to play tennis with these "bats"! Or was this "Irish Rules" tennis - if your opponent doesn't play fair bop them with a croquet hammer?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/silensol] You're absolutely right! I make it Women 6 : Men 1 (fob watches disqualified)

comment.author: 91870729@N06
comment._content: www.stannestennis.com says the club was founded in 1954 at John's Hill Waterford. Perhaps 1954 was a rebirth. I am sure they would like a copy of this interesting photo.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/silensol] History here "Prior to 1954, two tennis clubs were operating in the Johnas Hill area of Waterford. The older club was called Waterford Lawn Tennis Club and it operated in the grounds currently occupied by St. Anne's-Waterford Tennis Club. Tennis was played on grass courts at the Waterford Lawn Tennis Club.The second club operating in the Johna's Hill area was called St. Anne's Lawn Tennis Club and was in the grounds of the County Hospital on the land on which the new Cheshire Homes are now built. Tennis was played on the St. Anne's courts from the mid 1920's."

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: I would think that some of the "lads" in the back row are there hoping for more than a few double faults!!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The OS 25" shows the Waterford Lawn Tennis club (at the site of the modern club). If this club played where the modern Cheshire homes are, this picture with a wall and mature trees behind must be along this boundary, and the trees are still there in Streetview

comment.author: 101084800@N03
comment._content: yep they joined up in 1954,great letter in deise magasine ,,annabelle torrie describing conditions during civil wat 1921 or there abouts have photos of st annes club

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/101084800@N03] Great to have confirmation of the 1954 merger, thank you.
